Posts.Content: JudyO wrote: This afternoon I went for a 4 month follow up appointment with my oncologist. I was on a 3 month schedule until I hit 3 years and then it was changed to 4 months. I will be 5 years out next month and thought maybe he would change the schedule to 6 months. He said no I will continue on 4 month follow ups. I really don't see a need for such frequent follow ups. The nurse does a quick questionaire and take the vitals. He hasn't done blood work in about a year now, all he does is a quick examine of the breast area. He feels since I had so many lymph nodes positive (7) I am at a high risk and need to be watched closer than some. I wouldn't argue with that but don't feel his examines would find anything anyway. Just curious what the follow up is for some of you. ( I live in the USA) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Follow up appointments JudyO Maggs09

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 12:33PM JudyO wrote: I took a looksie....looks like it says updated 2009 but something is off here...notice no % for stage 3c....might this be because this was before the staging was changed. That would make this old data. I think I saw this somewhere else and if I recall it is from some time period before 2000. It is from the american surgeon data if I recall.
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 04:04PM - edited Oct 29, 2009 04:06PM by JudyO Beverly....I found the information on taxol on this sight. If you go under treatments and then under chemo research the latest article is about taxol. It talks about chemo not working for the different types of bc. It looks like it works best on the triple negs that are basal cell....doesn't work on luminal a (which are ER+) and also doesn't do anything for triple negs that are non basal. It does work on luminal b (which are ER+, the more aggressive of these)...Read the article, it gives some percentages. I had read about the ER+ also on the american cancer sight where they said they were looking into chemo for ER+ and also adjuvant on line has information that states there is some questions regarding this. The information on this sight about taxol was published recently. The Her+ info I can't remember where I read that but I did see that. I know I read it in more than one article. I think there has been a question about the a for some time. I see that many clinics are now doing TC instead of AC then T. If I think of where I read this I will get back to you. Bev...since you are grade 3 you might be a luminal b so taxol may work for you....that is where I think they will start screening the biology of the tumors more.
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 04:15PM JudyO wrote: Shanagirl...I had AC then T...still is the recommendation for us stage 3....I think they are looking at the TC more to save the side effects from the A but my onc said there are 2 schools of thought regarding which is best....he is still ac and t....young onc pretty up on things
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 12:54PM JudyO wrote: PureE....I totally agree with you. That is exactly what I am saying about stats. Why are they all over the place.....and also why doesn't any one seem to be able to get a better handle on them. My onc did say that the her positives really messed up the old stats. He said if you had one side of the study with only a few her + and then the other side had a lot of the her + it could have totally negated the study. At least now they can separate this out but I am sure another thing will be discovered that will also make the stats off.....that is why we need to develop more towards individual biology. That would probably explain why a stage 1 will hit stage 4 and a bad stage 3 will never get there.
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: JudyO wrote: Last night I was on here and was reading through a thread. It suddenly changed to talk about survival stats. Someone noted that stage 3 has a 40% 8 year survival on webmd. I looked it up and yes that is what was posted and is current in 2009. I was surprised to see stage 2 has 70% and stage 1 has 90% for 8 years. People right away said this must be old data. I don't know if it is old data but I sure wish I knew where all of the different numbers come from. My onc gave me 50%, if you use adjuvant on line I get another number....then I ran cancer math got something else...and then I found a mayo clinic calculator and still another number. At least these last 3 were fairly similar. The biggest problem I had with these is the treatment. I had dose dense a/c and t but have now read that a/c works for herceptin positives not negatives which I am and that taxols don't work for most of the ER+, which I am. So does that mean I don't put them into the calculator and figure that they did nothing for me. I know many of the stats I read are from the late 1990s or early 2000s. Often they will tell you what time period. I also know some but not most don't do an age adjustment for mortality....most do though. The American Cancer Society does an age adjustment but doesn't go into stages...just regional...which is stage 2 and 3 combined. The 5 year survival is about 85% and the ten year is about 70%. Most dx are stage 2 so us stage 3 may be below this number. That stat just came out in the last month. It use data from 2000 to 2005. Only change from this would be more use of herceptin. That could bring the numbers up a couple of points but not many since under 25% are her + and if 70% of the 25% has an increase in survival of 50% it would only bring this number up less than 4% to maybe 74%. My onc nurse said they were using herceptin in so many clinical trials before 2005 that most people had it long before it was approved in 2005. So far no one has said the AIs impact survival just recurrence. The 8 year figures on arimidex does not show less deaths. I know zometa is hot but other than the one Australian study no survival stat has been given for this. Another sight I reviewed is the cancer survival by stage in uk breast cancer. They just updated this last fall and added 2% to the survival rates. Their data is from 2005.....and from what I see not much has increased since then. Another problem with the stats is that they changed the staging criteria during the time some of this data was collected. They took out the better prognosis and put it into stage 2 so that stage may have a better stat than what is shown. My onc said that lymph nodes is the biggest factor in survival. That is what the new staging is trying to address. I think the biggest problem is no one has a handle on the stats. You would think with data collection and current computers they would be able to get better stats but from what I see this isn't the case. I look at my stats and get sad ...but I also pray and cross my fingers I will have some time so maybe something will come out to help me when I need it. I know they say don't look at stats but I think it is our human nature to want to have some idea....but these stats just give me frustration..... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 03:06PM JudyO wrote: I think the non-compliance thing is huge but I also thing the non-compliance happens mostly in the stage 1 people. They usually aren't as frightened by this as we are. I would never think of not doing what I was told. I think when looking at stats it is important to look at where they came from. The adjuvant on line stats probably contain a lot of the non compliance people. They start out using data from seers which uses the actual number of deaths each year. I believe when you look at well monitored clinical studies done by good institutions you will get a more accurate picture.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 04:12PM JudyO wrote: My onc told me one of the reasons they are doing neo-adjunctive chemo more now is it is a great way to see what works on who....much easier and better than running clinical trials...and no one has anything to lose from it.
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 11:15AM JudyO wrote: Stage 3 and grade 1 lobular dx may 2008..age 56. Coming up on 5 years now. Had bmx, dd ac and  dd t, 25 rads, and arimidex. Not doing anything natural. Sometimes I wonder if the chemo was worth it. From what I read it may not work well on grade 1. I am not sure if it was the chemo or the arimidex but I am not the same energetic person I was before all of this. My onc strongly felt I needed the chemo. Wish they would have had something for stage 3 like the onco type test they do for stage 1 and stage 2 to tell me the benefits of chemo. Overall my health has been great and most days I can forget about my cancer. On occasion I do think about the next 5 years and hope that I will not have a recurrence but it does not consume my thoughts anymore. The initial treatments are only a distant memory at this point. Best of luck if you are just starting this journey.

Posts.Title: Does a bone density test show mets? JudyO soprano

Posts.Content: JudyO wrote: Hi everyone, just needed to vent somewhere. Tonight on our local news they interviewed the lady who is the cure honorary survivor for our upcoming race. She went on to say how horrible it was to hear the news from a phone call she received from her doctor while in her car with her family. She talked about her struggles etc. Turns out she only had DCIS. From what I have read considered more pre cancerous and very highly curable. I felt they missed the boat in not having someone with stage 4 or having had a recurrence selected. In my mind those are the people we should be honoring. I doubt this women even had chemo. Sorry for my rant, just feel many people don't get the real stories out there. I know a lot of people who think breast cancer is curable! And if you do get it and die it was only because you didn't get you mamos when you should have. Lot of ignorance out in the general public. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mad tonight at Susan Komen JudyO april485

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2014 03:33PM JudyO wrote: Just checked out Bestbirds blog, excellent article we need more of this info out....we need money for the cure!...and also more education, another thing the general public don't get is that breast cancer people aren't free of the worry just because we made 5 years....
Posts.Title: Mad tonight at Susan Komen JudyO april485

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:21AM JudyO wrote: Karen 1956....www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1248209720080812 is one sight that mentions the grade 1 tumors...I can't find it now but there was a study I heard about on the national news a while back and when I followed up on it they also mentioned the grade 1 tumors. barbe 1958....I don't know if I am cured. My onc does use the word cured. He tells stage 4 they are treatable and doesn't give them any time limits...a very good friend of mine is stage 4 ILC and he is always very encouraging to her.... she is now out over 4 years as a stage 4....and he once told me you may be cured, I just don't know who is and who isn't..some are cured with surgery, some are cured with the current treatments, some just die before it has a chance to recur and some are not cured, it will come back ...a real crap shoot....I like the way he thinks....
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 08:24PM JudyO wrote: I have a question regarding the 50% mets. If 50% get mets why is the current survival rate for breast cancer at 90% for 5 years, 82% for 10 years and 75% for 15 years. These are the current stats from the American Cancer Society and it also states not to look at the figures that are years out because they do not reflect current treatments. If 50% get mets you would think at least by year 15 the stat would have a survival of only 50%. Also I can't understand if 50% get mets what are the figures we get from adjuvant online, they are usually much better than 50%.
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 09:08PM JudyO wrote: After my last post I left the sight and took a long bubble bath. I thought some about this thread. I think as well as finding a cure they need to find a way to tell people if/when they are cured. Most stage 1 are cured, many stage 2 are cured and a lot of stage 3 are cured. Often the surgery is the cure. But right now they can't tell who is "cured" so they push treatments on everyone. At least at stage 1 and 2 the onco test is starting to give them an idea of their status. But us stage 3 women are always in limbo. I also think they need to develop something that better tells us at what year we can breathe a little easier. A recent study out of MD Anderson had the stage 1, 2, and 3 recurrences about the same in the 5 to 10 year period. They said the bad stage 3 women occur in the first 5 years. The biggest recurrence in the 5 to 10 year period was stage 3 grade 1 tumors. That made sense to me since grade 1 tumors are slow growers and probably take longer to present as stage 4. The grade 3 fast growers no matter what stage will go to stage 4 quicker usually.
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 08:11PM JudyO wrote: It has been a long time since anyone visited this topic but I would like to add some info. I wasn't about to get into adjuvant online since I am not a doctor but found a research site on the internet that is open to anyone. It is being developed at Harvard. It lets you put in your statistics and gives you the outcome depending on the treatment you select. Thnigs that affect your outcome...age ( younger people respond better to chemo), size of tumor (you enter each mm), number of positive lymph nodes, ER, PR and HER status (interesting that ER/PR have a better prognosis but they do not respond to chemo as well), type (lobular is a little better than ductal!) and grade. You can enter the different treatments and see you outcome. This site is researching the use of math statistics and is different from adjuvant online which is more based on actual case numbers. I found it very interesting. If you do a google search for breast cancer mortality or for breast cancer life math you should find this sight.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2009 03:34PM JudyO wrote: Carol....I agree with everyone...I am surprised that if the 3 were positive they didn't automatically remove more...my surgeon said he would remove as many as he thought he needed to get where things were clean...I had 7+ out of 14 they took....from what I hear you can even have negative nodes and then hit a positive one...I know someone where number 1 was good but 2 was bad so they took out more.....I think part of the benefit from radiation is to hit anything that was left...that is why with 7+ nodes I had radiation on my neck and chest....I was told that should zap any strays in those areas.....I had one breast removed but feel very nervous about the other so my onc said sure we can remove that one too....I think a good onc will tell you what they think is best but will also look at how you feel.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 12:16AM - edited Nov 3, 2010 12:17AM by JudyO The other oncs at my clinic tell the girls not to dye their hair but my onc who is rather handsome and young said I would never take that away from any woman...I have a wife and mother, and I know that is something I would never tell them not to do. Quality of life is important too...my hair came back mostly grey...bring on the color....it made me feel alive again...and not so worn down.
Posts.Title: Who dyes their hair? Mom3 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 05:48PM JudyO wrote: Hate to say this girls but I got a  50% from my onc. I have more nodes + than most but have a small tumor, am grade 1, and am post meno ER+ so arimidex works really well on me....my onc said 50 %...I said before any treatment....I had ddAC and dd Taxol...radiation and now arimidex...hoping to do zometa soon...mast on one breast and second going soon...and he says no the 50% is what I have with doing all of this...probably 100% chance of recurrence if I didn't do anything....I have done some research and I think he is off but I know you will find these stats if you just look at sights like the American Cancer...Mayo clinic also says 67% for 5 year survival for stage 3....numbers are out there all over the place....best to ignore them....
Posts.Title: Should I get a new surgery ?????? Mamita49 JudyO

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 05:32PM JudyO wrote: Thanks to all of you. I am keeping busy and am getting better with dealing with this. A year ago I never had any free time where I wasn't thinking about this. I couldn't even sit down and read a book, something I always liked to do. I didn't work any while doing chemo and rads, thought I would just read and read. Couldn't concentrate. I remember going to the movie MaMa Mia....normally I would have been dancing in my seat. I sat the whole time thinking about the cancer. At least now, one year later I can enjoy these things again. I think part of the down feeling right now is do to the fact that I am going to have the other breast removed. I am happy they are doing it but it does bring back the memories. I also got an invitation to my class reunion. We all like to go to those looking our best. All I thought of was my 2 missing "boobs" and the little gray fuzz I have that replaced my hair. I get mad at myself for being so vain. During my chemo I got 2 surprise letters from grade school friends I hadn't seen in probably 30 years. That had heard about me from my father. So a big part of me knows most people care about me not the package I come in. Thanks again for the caring thoughts...
Posts.Title: One year ago JudyO JudyO

Posts.Content: JudyO wrote: I am Judy. A few months back I was very active on this board. Then one day I posted in the stage 4 forum. I said some things that were taken TOTALLY NOT how  I had meant them and then tried to say how sorry I was, this got me even harsher words back. I am very sensitve and had many tears over this. This week it will be one year for me. The last couple of months I had a scare that turned out okay but it has caused me to have my other breast removed next week. Right now one of our local hospitals is running an ad about mamograms....bettter than 98% stage 1 ...5 year survival comes on every few hours. I never missed a mamo or any physical and I ended up stage 3. I cry every day over this...the why me? is so great sometimes. The unknown we all face is so scary. I hope they find a better way to find this monster. I hope that they find better tools to let us know what treatment will work best for us and what our survival statistic really is. And I hope and pray hard for a cure. I am very thankful for one year and hope for many more. I must say though that a side of me also says that is one less year you may have left to live...before the beast comes back. The dark shadows of our minds can be a terrible thing. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: One year ago JudyO JudyO

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 12:11PM JudyO wrote: Want to add a big thank you from me. Some days when I am feeling the fear I get on here and read the success stories...helps me get to the end of the day. I hope some day to be one of the success stories and I will post on here so I can encourage someone.
Posts.Title: Thank you to those who come back and give us hope! everyminute helena67

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 02:48PM JudyO wrote: Marsha....You have sent me some encouraging words over the last few months. Thank you...You need to keep up that humor and spirit. When I read some of your posting I thought there is someone who is going to live her life and not let this c stuff take it away from her. I went to Chicago last weekend and went to Second City. Laughed my ass off and you know what.... I thought of you...yes, I swear I did because somewhere if I remember correct I read you were into plays/humor. No one knows when the end will come. Right now you and I are thinking more of the end...but we shouldn't stop living...I am off to Mexico the middle of the month. I plan on making the most of my life....I have 2 sons and plan on working hard to create happy memories for them...it is a good thing that you and I are aware of this....we are more apt to work at creating these memories with the ones we love. Plan trips...go for it girl...don't have any regrets...Judy
Posts.Title: I want my social life back! marshakb LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 09:52PM JudyO wrote: Thank you...needed a boost today and you provided it.
Posts.Title: A Couple Of Success Stories Pure gillyone

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 09:06PM JudyO wrote: When I was dx 2 1/2 years ago my onc was certain that zometa would soon be part of the standard care. My husband is a dentist so I was familiar with the possible negatives of zometa. We talked several times with my onc. After I completed chemo he agreed to submit to my insurance for the zometa. Of course it was denied since it is not the current approved treatment. I offered to pay for the zometa out of pocket but my onc said no. He said it would probably be a waste of money and he didn't feel would change my outcome so he would not give it to me.
Posts.Title: Zometa - Latest News out of San Antonio Meeting voraciousreader Gitane
